node.text: In a bid to chip away at the remaining hesitancy regarding makeup on men, we asked the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers to do a pair of video tutorials demonstrating looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In the one shown here, she realizes a look inspired by the 1998 film “Velvet Goldmine,” with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect is meant to be one of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. Visit tmagazine.com for more. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Makeup for Men, or Anyone: Full-Face Glam

node.text: As part of T’s Beauty & Luxury issue, the writer @MeganEOGrady explores what makeup means to the growing group of men who have embraced it. Her piece is accompanied by photos of models with faces done by the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers, who, in a bid to make such adornment less intimidating, breaks down her process in a pair of video tutorials, demonstrating what she calls two “simplistic and masculine” looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In one video, she shares tips for creating dewy skin accented with a vivid swipe of color across the lids, and in another, she realizes a more classically glamorous visage with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect of both styles is a kind of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. See more on tmagazine.com. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Minimal Makeup Looks for Men — or Anyone

node.text: A brief history of how New York’s Sag Harbor became a refuge for African-American families, with testimonials from some of the residents who’ve summered there for much of their lives. Read Sandra E. Garcia's (@s_evangelina) accompanying story on this close-knit community on tmagazine.com. Video by @JoshuaKissi. Produced by Tom Delavan (@tdelavan).

node.title: Long Island's Enduring Black Beachfront Community

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Feb. 25 and 26, 2020, T gathered seven established black actresses — all of whom got their start decades ago, working across various mediums — for a group and cover shoot by the photographers @MickaleneThomas and @RacquelChevremont in Los Angeles, California. In it, these women — @HalleBerry, Angela Bassett (@im.angelabassett), @TarajiPHenson, Mary J. Blige (@therealmaryjblige), Lynn Whitfield (@mslynnwhitfield), @ViolaDavis and Kimberly Elise (@ikimberlyelise) — remember their first roles and discuss the solidarity they feel with one another. “We are living in an age in which some of our greatest, most successful actors are black women, near 50 or older, veterans who have fought against an industry that for much of its history would have rather ignored them,” writes @BrianKeithJackson in the accompanying story. Read more on Tmagazine.com. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Oct. 15, 2018, T gathered 32 black American male poets, playwrights and novelists — writers whose work is so crucial to our understanding America itself — at the Brooklyn Historical Society for a group portrait creative directed by @BootsRiley and this accompanying short film by @YvonneMichelleShirley. In it, these men reflect on their experiences and quote from some of their favorite works by black female American writers, whose voices are equally powerful and necessary. As Audre Lorde once said, “We don't only write about ourselves, we use ourselves to illuminate something that we really believe and we really feel.” Read the accompanying story, and why we chose to focus specifically on black men for this piece, on Tmagazine.com. You’ll also find a reading list chosen by these men of their favorite black female writers.

node.title: On Being a Black Male Writer in America

node.text: Around the country, restaurants are expanding their menus of thoughtful, complex, nonalcoholic cocktails to keep pace — especially this month — with a population that’s drinking less. And while these drinks are made for adult palates, they’re also drawing an unexpected fan base: children. T hosted a taste test, inviting children of the magazine’s staff and writers to assess several mocktails at @ReceptionBar.NYC, a modern Korean spot on Manhattan’s Lower East Side. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: Block Shop Textiles printer Mukesh Chhipa works on a paper block print in the village of Bagru.

node.title: Ancient Art of Block Printing in Jaipur

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 07, 2021. May be an image of food and outdoors.

node.text: Daniela Vargas Dieppa, Ramya Giangola, Sofia Ajodan and Jessica Flesh don’t just work in fashion; they eat, sleep and breathe it. And after a trip to Baja California’s Valle de Guadalupe winemaking region, they were determined to drink it, too. Thus El Vino was born, a sort of wine-of-the-month club in which painstakingly sourced bottles are beautifully packaged with specially designed labels and paired with objets created by artists and designers. “It’s as much about what’s on the outside of the bottle as it is about the inside,” says Giangola. The group’s first release, a Baja rosé made by fourth-generation vintner Lulu Martinez Ojeda, is both crisp and sweet, with floral and fruity notes, and comes adorned with a label painted by the Marrakech-based line LRNCE, which also created a line of ceramics that echo the label’s whimsically biomorphic artwork. Click the link in our bio for more. Written by Eleonore Condo, photo by @PiaRiverola. #TList

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 07, 2021. May be an image of living room.

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: Ray and Charles Eames in the Eames House residence living room, Case Study #8, in the Pacific Palisades, photographed in 1958. Photo by Julius Shulman, © J. Paul Getty Trust. Getty Research Institute, Los Angeles.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 06, 2021 tagging @hejishin. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text: Among the 25 Things lists from T’s archive that we’re revisiting this week is 2019’s compilation of 25 artworks that define the contemporary age. As always, there was much debate among the judges who compiled it, but a kind of consensus was reached. Included on the final list was @HejiShin’s “Baby” (series) from 2016, in which the artist took on the subject of childbirth, capturing the moments after crowning. She illuminated some of the undeniably gory scenes with a scorching red light. Other pictures are barely lit at all, and the puckered faces of the almost-born emerge from menacing black shadows. While these photographs might remind us of our common humanity, they are hardly sentimental or celebratory — several are downright scary, and this complexity is at the core of Shin’s practice. Her photographs do not answer any questions. Instead, they ask a lot of their audiences. Click the link in our bio for the full list. Image courtesy of Galerie Buchholz, Berlin/Cologne.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 06, 2021 tagging @mrsjesscc, @blaineduh, and @rawlinsdesign. May be an image of furniture and indoor.

node.text: One often hears that a home has “good bones.” The phrase is not typically applied to an entire neighborhood, but that’s exactly how the architect and historian Christopher Rawlins (@rawlinsdesign) describes Manhattan’s Inwood, which has one of the highest concentrations of Art Deco buildings in the United States, and is where he’s lived since 1999. Initially, he and his then-partner, the artist Tad Mike, purchased two units in the same 1935 cream brick co-op — a 700-square-foot one-bedroom to live in, and a 1,050-square-foot two-bedroom two floors below to use for their studios. After Rawlins performed “a very faithful, very surgical Art Deco kind of renovation” on the smaller unit, though, the apartment next to the one that housed the couple’s studios became available, so they sold the one-bedroom and, in 2007, bought that adjoining space. Rawlins then embarked on a second renovation, this one years long and a chance, he decided, not to ignore the building’s history but to be less by the book. Pictured here, however, is the combined space’s foyer, a somewhat formal element that was never in jeopardy, as Rawlins considers a foyer to be a crucial element of a successful New York City apartment — “a threshold between the chaos of the city and the calm of a successful home,” he says. Click the link in our bio to see more. Written by Jessica Cumberbatch Anderson (@mrsjesscc), photo by Blaine Davis (@blaineduh).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 06, 2021 tagging @yaelbartana. May be an image of railroad and nature.

node.text: “Redemption Now,” an ambitious solo exhibition of work by the Israeli-born, Berlin-and-Amsterdam-based feminist artist @YaelBartana, opened earlier this summer in the Daniel Libeskind-designed Jewish Museum in Berlin. For more than two decades, Bartana has been playing with historical narratives and examining ideas of collective identity using photography, installation and video. The centerpiece of the current show, “Malka Germania” (Hebrew for “Queen Germania”), is a 43-minute-long video and sound installation that was commissioned by the museum. Projected onto three large screens, it presents an alternate vision of Germania — which is what Hitler was to rechristen Berlin as should he have won the war and moved ahead with razing and remaking the city in an image of hypertrophied neo-Classicism complete with a gigantic capitol dome. In Bartana’s reimagining, an androgynous female messiah figure marches with a donkey through a modern-day version of Berlin with street signs in Hebrew. Click the link in our bio for more. Written by Gisela Williams (@giselaatlarge). #TList

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 05, 2021. May be an image of tree and mountain.

node.text: #T25Buildings: In his design for a thermal spa built over natural hot springs in the Swiss mountain village of Vals, the architect Peter Zumthor used 60,000 slabs of locally quarried quartzite — a stone created during the formation of the Alps some 50 million years ago from geologic elements that might be as much as six times older than that — to erect what you could easily mistake for a forgotten ruin excavated from a hillside. The main structure projects from the slope as a solid rectangular mass, its face punctured by square windows and voids. Winding pathways traverse the interior like tunnels into ancient tombs. Manipulating light and darkness, those channels control access to spectacular views of the surrounding Alpine massif, while variations in water temperature — the pools range from 57 to 97 degrees — generate their own dramatic shifts in atmosphere, from the chill of a glacial lake to the dense steam of a Turkish bath. Therme Vals draws on the essential structures of the region: quarries and bridges, traditional stone rooftops and the cathedral-like interior of the Albigna Dam near the Italian border. Click the link in our bio for T’s full list of the 25 most significant works of postwar architecture.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 05, 2021. May be a closeup of flower and nature.

node.text: Triadic (@tri_adic), an international creative agency founded by the curator @RoyaSachs, the creative director @MafaldaMillies and the producer Elizabeth Edelman (@lizardedelman), specialized in staging collaborative performance art pieces. Then came the pandemic. To continue to foster what Sachs describes as creative “cross-pollination” and “playful interaction,” the trio launched a digital initiative in which artists were invited to submit a still-life image and text that reflected their experiences during lockdown. “We wanted a format that was simple enough for holistic storytelling but broad enough to give people artistic freedom,” says Sachs. The resulting book, “Still Here: Moments in Isolation,” which will be published by the German imprint Distanz on Sept. 21, compiles 127 of these works from contributors such as the fine artists Wolfgang Tillmans and Elizabeth Peyton, the author Chris Kraus and the neuroscientist Mendel Kaelen. Click the link in our bio for more. Written by @AlwaCooper. Pictured: Wolfgang Tillmans’s (@wolfgang_tillmans) “Clipped Tulip” (2020). #TList

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 05, 2021 tagging @stefanruizphoto, @kkaa_official, and @nikilsaval. May be an image of indoor.

node.text: This week, we published T’s list of the 25 most significant buildings erected or updated since World War II, which included structures — from Le Corbusier’s monastery of Sainte Marie de la Tourette in Éveux, France, to Lina Bo Bardi’s SESC Pompéia in São Paulo, Brazil — located all over the world and representative of various styles and typologies. Head to T’s Instagram Stories for more articles, pulled from T’s archive, for architecture lovers. Pictured here is the interior of Fujiya ryokan, which features in @NikilSaval’s piece on Kengo Kuma (@kkaa_official). Photo by Stefan Ruiz (@stefanruizphoto).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 04, 2021. May be an image of twilight and outdoors.

node.text: #T25Buildings: “I’ve always been drawn to making things as simple as possible, if you can do that without making them inhuman or dull or oppressive,” said the American architect Edward Larrabee Barnes in 1989, 28 years after completing his landmark campus for the Haystack Mountain School of Crafts. Designed as an initial cluster of 26 cedar-shingled volumes connected by wooden decks and platforms — more a village than a building — the project takes the vernacular of saltbox cottages with steeply pitched roofs from New England’s rural and coastal communities and abstracts it. Lifted on stilts over a wooded granite slope, the structures (later expanded to 36 under Barnes’s eye) look out over the steel blue water of Jericho Bay, their rooflines set at 45-degree angles like saplings seeking light. Still used today for artists’ residencies and workshops, the welcoming, lucid design has, for more than half a century, provided fertile ground for creatives, including such visitors as the textile designer Anni Albers, the glass blower Dale Chihuly and the ceramist and painter Toshiko Takaezu. Click the link in our bio for T’s full list of the 25 most influential buildings erected — or cleverly updated — since World War II. Image courtesy of Amanda Kowalski.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 04, 2021 tagging @danilo.scarpati. May be an image of indoor.

node.text: In light of this week’s publication of #T25Buildings, our list of the most significant works of postwar architecture, we’re revisiting 2019’s #T25Rooms, for which a six-person jury — Tom Delavan (@tdelavan), Toshiko Mori (@toshiko.mori), #DanielRomualdez, Suzanne Slesin (@suzyslesin), @GabrielHendifar and Simon Watson (@simonpwatson) — met and debated and made a list of the most influential rooms of all time. Rooms that, above all, offered a new kind of visual lexicon. Among the selections was Ricardo Bofill’s living room at La Fábrica, a 32,000-square-foot former cement factory in Sant Just Desvern, Spain (1975) that illustrates architectural postmodernism at its most inspiring. With over 30 concrete silos, cavernous machine rooms and nearly 2.5 miles of underground tunnels, this reimagining was a mammoth undertaking that is, decades later, still in process. The central living room features two stories of arches, exposed pipes and oversize billowing white drapes. Click the link in our bio for the full list of rooms. Written by @KurtSoller, photos by @Danilo.Scarpati and @NachoAlegre.

node.text: #T25Buildings: From the early 1950s until his death in 1974, the Estonian American Louis Kahn developed a mystic architectural language all his own, using runic geometries and ritualistic chiaroscuro to turn galleries, university campuses and government offices into spaces of sublime meditation. No building on American soil comes closer to that transcendent power than his Salk Institute, a biological research facility in La Jolla, Calif., commissioned in 1960 by the inventor of the polio vaccine, Jonas Salk. Set on bluffs overlooking the Pacific, the center of the institute consists of two elongated blocks that face each other across a patio paved in travertine and bisected by a channel of water, like something from a Mughal garden. (Kahn had imagined this space filled with greenery, but Luis Barragán convinced him, ingeniously, to leave it blank.) The buildings themselves are innovative in their functionality — they remain in use as research laboratories, with dedicated utility floors that allow maintenance to be done without interrupting the lab’s activities. Click the link in our bio for T’s list of the most significant works of postwar architecture.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on August 03, 2021. May be an image of tree and outdoors.

node.text: #T25Buildings: Built of gray stone and concrete grown over with dense vegetation, Balkrishna Doshi’s 1983 campus for the Indian Institute of Management in the South Indian city of Bangalore synthesizes centuries of architectural history with rare subtlety. Its elegant arrangement of passageways, courtyards and gardens — set on a little over 13 acres — glances toward the layout of the briefly inhabited 16th-century city of Fatehpur Sikri in India’s north, conceived by the Mughal emperor Akbar in part to encourage civic engagement and debate. “My family is from Bangalore, and I have childhood memories of going to the campus, which is an extremely bucolic setting,” says the writer Nikil Saval. “It’s one of the best instances of a modern architect deferring to the landscape and to the culture of a city, as well as to indigenous architectural traditions.” Doshi’s structural rigor and material honesty — there are stone corridors and pergolas built with strict right angles and open to the lush environment that gives Bangalore its nickname, the Garden City — gesture toward the work of his teacher Le Corbusier, while the careful modulation of light and shadow suggest Louis Kahn’s work at his own IIM campus in Ahmedabad (Doshi worked closely with both architects on projects in his native India). Click the link in our bio for T’s full list of the most significant works of postwar architecture.
